Problems in Computing P(y|x1, x2, …, xd)
▪ When computing P(y|x1, x2, …, xd), we need to count nx|y and nx
– The number of training instances having the same attribute values as      
x = (x1, x2, …, xd) 
▪ However, as the number of attributes increases, fewer training 
instances will have the same attribute values
– (ex) x = (Age = 34, Weight = 55, Height = 160, Salary = 34000, …)
▪ This results in poor estimates of P(x1, x2, …, xd|y) and P(x1, x2,
…, xd)
– i.e., P(x1, x2, …, xd|y) = 0 and P(x1, x2, …, xd) = 0 for large d
– Especially when the size of training set is small
